Award.AwardTitle: Grain Boundary-Activity Relationships in CO2 Electroreduction Catalysis
Award.AbstractNarration:
Professor Matthew Kanan of the Department of Chemistry at Stanford University is supported by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Division of Chemistry to investigate a new design principle for catalysts that use electrical energy to convert carbon dioxide (CO2) into useful chemicals. These catalysts are of interest for applications in renewable energy storage and for making chemicals from CO2 instead of petroleum. The research focuses on materials known as metal nanoparticles (NPs), which are tiny pieces of metal with dimensions ranging from about 1 to 100 nanometers (ca. 5-50 atoms). The aim is to investigate how a particular type of defect in these particles, known as grain boundaries, affect catalysis. Grain boundaries provide unusual surface structures and catalytic properties that are often different from defect-free surfaces. The research aims to probe these unusual structures and to elucidate how they impact CO2 catalysis. In addition, metal NPs are widely used as catalysts for many industrially important, high-volume chemical reactions and this research may lead to improvements in those applications. On the educational front, CO2 recycling is being incorporated into educational material to enhance student awareness of the global carbon cycle, the formation of fossil fuels, and the flux of CO2 into the atmosphere from fossil fuel combustion.

The research encompasses two synergistic objectives: i) characterize grain boundary surface terminations on metal NPs with atomic-level resolution to assess the possible surface sites for catalysis ii) elucidate grain boundary-activity relationships in metal catalysts with different grain boundary densities and geometries. The structures of grain boundaries and their surface terminations are probed using a combination of high-resolution transmission electron microscopy, electron diffraction, and molecular dynamics simulations. Catalysts spanning a range of grain boundary densities and character distributions are prepared using established synthetic methods as well as new methods developed in this research. These properties are correlated to the CO2 electroreduction activity to establish quantitative grain boundary-activity relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overall objective of this project was to provide fundamental insights into how defects in materials affect their catalytic properties for electrochemical transformations. The project focused on defects known as grain boundaries, which are the interfaces between misaligned crystallites in a polycrystalline material. Specifically, the goal was to assess whether grain boundaries in Au materials create surfaces that are more active for electrochemical carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction to carbon monoxide (CO) than ordinary facets. In addressing this question, substantial effort was also devoted to advancing techniques for imaging grain and defect structures in materials.  

            The project contributed to advancing state-of-the-art techniques for materials characterization and obtained a set of results that shed light on the relationship between grain boundaries and CO2reduction. There were two major outcomes in the area of materials characterization. First, the project demonstrated that the underlying grain structure of nanoparticle materials can be mapped with high resolution and accuracy using techniques that are performed in a scanning electron microscope (SEM) as an alternative to more typical approaches that use transmission electron microscopes (TEM). The importance of this advance is that SEMs are more accessible and convenient to use than TEMs. Moreover, for certain highly polycrystalline materials, the project demonstrated that SEM-based techniques provide an interpretable grain map whereas TEM-based techniques do not. This advance is important for characterizing the relationship between grain structure and catalytic activity in heterogeneous catalysts, which are very commonly used in the chemical industry. 

            The second major outcome in materials characterization was an advance in a technique known as Bragg coherent X-ray diffraction imaging (BCDI). Prior to the work in this project, BCDI was developed as a technique to image discrete nanocrystals. The work in the project showed that BCDI could be used to image an individual crystallite (grain) in a continuous polycrystalline material during the application of external stimuli. The technique captures not only the shape of the grain, but also the defects within the grain (such as dislocations) and the grain boundaries surrounding the grain. The ability to image individual grains and their defects within polycrystalline materials is critical for understanding the relationship between catalytic or mechanical properties and the underlying grain structure. This technique is anticipated to aid the design of grain networks to achieve desired functional properties.  

            To address the key question of how grain boundaries affect catalytic activity for CO2reduction on Au materials, the project used a combination of grain mapping techniques and spatially resolved electrochemical measurements with sub-micron resolution. These studies provided direct evidence that the surface terminations of grain boundaries are more active than ordinary facets for CO2reduction, but not the competing, undesired H2O reduction reaction. To explain these results, a model was advanced wherein there is a high concentration of defects known as dislocations in the grain boundary vicinity and the dislocations lead to highly stepped surfaces that are uniquely active for CO2reduction. The project established key infrastructure to enable this relationship to be probed in greater depth in future studies. 

            To achieve the Broader Impact educational goals of the project, the PI introduced energy transduction and carbon dioxide fixation into the curriculum for an undergraduate organic chemistry course at Stanford. Specifically, the PI showed how the content of introductory organic chemistry can explain the central chemistry of the citric acid cycle and the Calvin cycle – the key cycles for chemical energy transduction in biochemistry. These cycles are juxtaposed with traditional introductory synthetic organic chemistry to highlight the key thermodynamic and kinetic features of biochemical systems that enable the energy of organic molecules to power living systems. In addition, the Calvin cycle is used to highlight the fundamental challenges of CO2 fixation that have to be addressed to mitigate greenhouse gas emissions or create carbon-negative technologies.
